Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Two-Stage Turnbull-Cutait Pull-Through vs. Standard Coloanal Anastomosis

Trial_Design.evidence: Eligible patients undergoing ultralow anterior rectal resection were randomised

Participants.evidence: Eligible patients undergoing ultralow anterior rectal resection were randomised to either the two-stage Turnbull-Cutait pull-through or standard hand-sewn coloanal anastomosis with diverting ileostomy.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to either the two-stage Turnbull-Cutait pull-through or standard hand-sewn coloanal anastomosis with diverting ileostomy

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was 30-day postoperative morbidity.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Neither patients nor surgeons were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety-two patients were randomised, with 46 in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 30-day postoperative complication rate was 34.8% in the two-stage group and 45.7% in the standard group (difference = -10.9, 95% CI, -29.5 to 8.9; P = .40).

Harms.evidence: The 30-day postoperative complication rate was 34.8% in the two-stage group and 45.7% in the standard group
